data.event: Founded in 1908, the town was named after Ely Parker, the first Native American commissioner for the U.S. government.

event.title: was surveyed and laid out in 1909

data.event: The original town site of Parker was surveyed and laid out in 1909 by a railroad location engineer by the name of Earl.

The town's name and origin began when a post office called Parker was established January 6, 1871, at Parker's Landing and the site of the Parker Indian Agency, named for Ely Parker, on the Colorado River Indian Reservation, 4 miles down river from the site of the railroad bridge of the modern town, to serve the Indian agency.
